Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 04:44AM westieluv wrote: I'm kicking myself for not taking the mammogram thing as seriously as I should have. I was a good girl at 40 and took the baseline....also went a year later....but then it seemed more of a hassle to get the thing done.  Truth was I have dense breasts and hated the procedure.  It was uncomfortable and I didn't have anyone in my immediate family with BC, so thought it was a little crazy to have to get one every year. Had a hysterectomy at 43 and things were ok.  My gyno quit practicing, so I waited about another 16 months before finally scheduling with another one that was closer to my home town.  This doc was nice enough and when he saw that I had not had a mamm in almost 4 years he got on to me a bit.  I told him that i had no family history with BC and just wasn't convinced that I needed get one every year.  When I found out that I didn't have to have a physican referral to get one, I decided I was being stupid and scheduled another mamm about 2 weeks after my gyno check. The mamm tech was nice, gentle....but I knew something was up when she came back and told me that there was a "wrinkle" in the films.  She moved the machine all sorts of ways and took only 1 view on my left breast and started filming the heck out of the right one.  I tried to be calm and convinced myself that it was really just a "wrinkle" and they always have trouble getting my breasts out from under my arm pit and up on the plate. Sure enough my primary physician called me the next week to say that they had compared this film to the last ones and that there were major changes and some suspicious abnormalities in the right breast.  I needed ultrasound right away and a biopsy was already scheduled for the following week.  A nurse of his called me back with an appt for the ultrasound at a Breast Center (attached to the local regional hospital) and gave me my appt time for meeting with a surgeon for the biopsy and consultation. I guess I should have been more chatty with the ultrasound tech and just asked "do these spots you are measuring line up with the microcalcifications on my mamm?"  There was a grouping of 4 microcalcifications that I could see and then another one extending on out. All the rest of the white matter on the mamm was so foreign to me that I couldn't make any sense out of it.  No one said anything to me about what type of biopsy they are going to do on me based on the ultrasound results.  Everything on my report says medial right breast....but the ultrasound tech was pushing down pretty hard into my chest wall to get her pictures and she wasn't messing around much with the rest of my breast that was laying over under my arm.  Going to look up stereotactic just in case this is where it is headed. Thursday can't get here fast enough.   My 20th wedding anniversary is Wednesday.  What a way to remember this event!
Posts.Title: Birad 4 microcalcifications westieluv teeyl

Posts.Content: westieluv wrote: Anxiety as a word seems so inadequate in describing how this feels! Had ultrasound Thursday and they measured and looked at 2 spots.  Compared all this to the mammography films.  Primary physician had called me at work saying I needed to pick up the films and reports and go to surgeons office in Breast Center for an ultrasound that day....Biopsy was already scheduled for following Thursday. Ultrasound tech measured and reviewed 2 spots that they measured and correlated with the mamm.  I expected some discussion of cysts, etc....but no, "just please be sure to be here on time for biopsy procedure".  "You will meet with surgeon first and then have procedure." Why can't they have someone at least talk with you to relieve fears, anxiety, etc.  I sooo wanted a discussion of cysts..   Seems like an eternity until I go for the biopsy and then from reading some of the posts, the waiting will continue. Have others had this type of experience at ultrasound appointments?  Beth - DCIS - bilateral :BMX 12-2010 with complications/Bilateral Latissmus dorsi Flap recon 3-2011 /Exchange Mentor Med Profile Silicone 450 07-2011/Revision to 400 on RT side 11-2011 Dx 9/13/2010, DCIS, 1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Birad 4 microcalcifications westieluv teeyl

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 09:03PM westieluv wrote: Hello Ladies! Got my last drain removed today.  YEAH!  I celebrated by getting a couple of mastectomy bras and 2 Amoena leisure weighted forms.  Can't officially wear them yet, but when I am more healed, I will at least look more normal. Yesterday, I put on a shirt, glanced in the mirror and had a flash back to when I was 10 years old.  I swear, my chest (physique) looked like I did at 10.  Weird, weird.  Guess that's why I decided to get myself something to fill in the concave and make me feel my age.  Wouldn't have been such an issue if my face looked like I was 10 instead of 47! Working on healing up until next appt with PS for discussion on what can be done re-constructively.  My tissue necrosis on the left has slowed.  I highly recommend that silvadene (sp?) prescription cream.  It's helping me grow some new skin over there. I read all the post-op posts and feel a kindred bond.  All going through same sorts of things to various degrees.  We need to listen to our bodies and take the time to heal. As you might have guessed by now, I am type A professional and had to make the decision today that I will need to take off another 30 days in this process due to the unusual nature of my surgery setbacks.   I'm the type who had a hysterectomy and went back to work in 2 weeks with a full load.  I'm usually going mach 5 whirlwind and I get results and get er done.  This situation has put me on my knees.  One minute I am fine, and the next minute I am crying and filled with profound sadness.  I have realized that the sadness comes from my loss of control over this aspect of my life.  I always said I knew that God was in control, but I guess he really has been in the back seat as I drove through life just asking occasionally which turn to take. Well, listening to Him and this body means that I can't do what I usually do and I have to say NO to alot of business situations and home life expectations.  I tell myself it's just for a season and that getting myself through all of this in 2011 will mean that I can get to a new version of normal by fall 2011...God willing. For the vast majority of the ladies on this forum, your surgery journey will go well and uneventful. It won't be without challenges, but remember that there are others here and in your personal life to help you get through the rough spots. On with plan B or C....I can take it. BMX - TE (removed due to complications along with loss of NS in procedure) Multi-focal DCIS in Rt Breast, AHP, LCIS & other multi-focal abnormalities in Lt Breast.  Breast cellulitis, necrosis in left breast tissue among other complications. Beth - westieluv

As usual, I have to wait over another weekend for results.  The breast surgeon is supposed to call me on Monday. Still waiting and praying for another B9.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 10:44AM westieluv wrote: Well, I didn't get so lucky. Surgeon called me this morning to tell me I have DCIS in this biopsy but they suspect more cancer by the radiology views they are seeing.  He is concerned I may have mixed type of cancer in the dense tissue?  The local breast surgeon does not feel comfortable about my situation.  He is referring me to IU medical center in Indianapolis for evaluation and treatment.  He mentioned the possible need for a mast on this breast.  Obviously, I am shell shocked right now.  My husband did not take the news too well either.  I have to break the news to my Mom and my 2 boys.  My oldest son is in college (2nd year) and the youngest is a Junior in high school.

Posts.Content: westieluv wrote: Back again.  In August of 2008, had mammograms, ultrasound, microcalcifications and ultrasound guided core biopsy - B9.  Still Birad-5 on every scan.  Things went ok for awhile and I am closely followed with frequent screenings.  Subsequent mamms showed changes in microcalcifications.  Jan 2010 I had green discharge from the one breast (same one they have always been screening heavily).  I took round of antibiotics and it cleared up.  Had another ultrasound in April.  No call back after that one.  I went in for digital mamm again in August.  As usual, they called me back in for magnified views and another ultrasound, and now have a stereotatic core biopsy scheduled for 09-09.  Surgeon's Nurse said cluster of microcalcifications and a lesion.  I have very dense breasts (age 47).  Nurse said ultrasound didn't help them much in evaluating and that I need the biopsy. I'm really not scared about the biopsy, but the recurring issues with the one breast are concerning.  It is getting old waiting and worrying.   I'm hoping for B9 again.  Are there people like me that keep going through this again and again? Better to be cautious than unaware.

I just want to grasp enough that I understand what the next surgeon will be discussing and I don't glaze over in shock while I'm there.  My husband is my rock and he will be there to help me listen and grasp what is going on next.  I also have a strong faith in my God and that's the strength that will get me through anything. I may post on another board whenever I figure out which one really applies to me.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 01:39PM westieluv wrote: ~Mar~ - if the drainage is anything other than blood colored, or yellowish to clear, call your doctor just to be on the safe side.  Also check to see that you don't have a clot string that is stuck in the line. The infection kicked me down.  It's 13 days out from first surgery and 3 days out from the second surgery, so I am doing good to shower, take my meds, type a little on here and sit in the recliner.  I'm happy just to be able to do that.  I hope to be able to sit up for a Christmas Eve dinner with my family and visit a little tomorrow with them.  Small things, I know, but meaningful to me. Beth

Planning to freeze some meals this weekend and hopefully finish all my Christmas shopping. I wish you all quick recoveries and a good start to life without BC.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 03:47PM westieluv wrote: Thank you to everyone for the hugs and uplifting messages.  I had never had a surgical complication on anything before and I didn't want to accept what had happened.  I was so sure that everything would go as planned.  I hate being SuzyDowner and I keep saying "I didn't consent to this outcome!" I had never looked at post mastectomy bras or supplies and it came down on me like a ton of bricks when the PS gave me a brochure and told me to make an appt with the people.  I'm looking at about a year of surgeries in the NEW plan the surgeons have made to fix me up.   He wants the prostheses folks to come up with varied sizes on forms that will help balance me during the next year while he "works" on me. I guess my feelings of feminity were tied to immediately reconstructed foobs. I had this timeline in my head and thought I could get through the initial plan.   I had not thought of how I would cope if things didn't go accordingly to plan. I have alot of general body swelling. My abdomen is blowed up like an apple.  I had to resort to some pretty harsh laxatives to get things moving.  What's causing all this general swelling all over my body?  Do I need to do something to help my body recover from the shock?
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 05:23PM westieluv wrote: BJB1, For me, the decision was emotional and financial.  Everytime I had to go back in for another biopsy procedure I was out $5,000 deductoble + out of pocket maximums.  I've been on this roller coaster since 2008 and enough is enough.  I just decided that I wasn't that "in love" with the tissue on my chest to keep up the procedures.  Once a BC diagnosis, they biopsy just about anything else that comes up.  I just couldn't take anymore lets wait and see and then go at it again. Each person's threshold for how much is enough, recurrence risks, etc is individual.  If you feel that lumpectomy is right for you....do it.  In the end, it's only your decision and you are the one that lives through the experience.  There is no right way. In my case, they said lumpectomy possible....then looked at the various areas of DCIS and said....well, no....you need MX.  I have a feeling that my ride is just beginning.  I hope I'm wrong...but I know my body. You know your body too and what you can handle physically and emotionally.  Be selfish right now, it's the time to take care of you!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 05:56PM westieluv wrote: Tissue in frozen section from left side showed atypical cells.  DCIS in areas of that breast too, or possibly IDC.  I'll know more when pathology comes back this week. I'm being told to adjust my expectations and give up the dream of good looking foobs with limited scars.  The PS actually gave me a brochure for a prosthetics shop when he came in to explain what went wrong.   I am beyond upset and I feel mutilated.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 11:19AM westieluv wrote: Hey Ladies, Just got home from another in hospital stay and surgery #2.  As I had posted earlier (12/10 BMX), I had less than routine surgery results with complications and then some.  After BMX that was supposed to be NS with TE bilaterally, I woke up with lots of tissue loss to left breast and a TE on right side only. Neither nipple was saved.  I was discharged from hospital next day following late afternoon surgery.  At first follow-up visit with breast surgeon 5 days later, they removed one of the three drains.  Drain on right side with TE was removed.  One drain on that side remained.  Continued tissue death on the left side was noted, but they sent me home to rest.  2 days later, I awoke with chills, fever and feeling that I was dying (not an exaggeration).  My husband called surgeon who said to go to ER.  PS on rounds had them hook me up to IV antibiotics and gave DX of breast cellulitis on the right side where TE was placed.  They admitted me to hospital again.  By the next day my regular PS visited and said it was not looking good and that the TE needed to come out along with some re-excision on the left side where tissue was continuing to die.  By then, I was feeling that I wanted to live without breasts as the infection continued to spread. I came through surgery #2 although I had tachycardia with very low blood pressures.  This had also been a complication of surgery #1.  I had never had this reaction to anesthesia before the BC diagnosis. Good news is that my pathology shows all cancer is out, I had atypical hyperplasia in the left nipple and areas of lobular cells that were atypical.  BS says I definitely would have had BC in left side as well.  Right side showed good margins with multi-focal grade 3 DCIS in 3-4 areas of the breast, so the area they biopsied was not all that was there. In hindsight, I wish there was a BC practice that specialized in women like me with dense breasts and almost NO fatty tissue in the breasts at all.  Had they known this by doing additional screening, I could have been prepared for the reality that I was not a candidate for TE and psychologically would have been better prepared to wake up to a radically different outcome. PS now wants to discuss doing a lattismus dorsal flap on both sides to try to give me some type of a breast form since I ended up with a radical BMX.  I'll listen to what he has to say and do my own research.  Cancer is out, but they still say I will need screening in future.  What they plan to screen....who knows.   I'm an aberration of a case.  Lumpectomy would have left me with months or years of undetected BC growing in right and left side, plus many more biopsies and other expensive tests.  I believe the BMX has saved my life.  I just need to figure out how my psych can develop a good self image with what is to come. I wish all who are going through this better cosmetic outcomes and most importantly a safe and successful journey to life without BC.
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer
